title: How to Put a Word Document on Your Website

steps.title: Open Google Drive.
steps.content: Open Google Drive. Go to https://drive.google.com/ in your web browser. This will open your Google account's Drive contents if you're logged in. If you aren't logged in, enter your email address and password first. You may need to click Go to Google Drive before proceeding.

steps.title: Click NEW.
steps.content: Click NEW . It's a blue button in the upper-left corner of the page. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click File upload.
steps.content: Click File upload . This is in the drop-down menu. Doing so will open a window.

steps.title: Select your Word file.
steps.content: Select your Word file. Double-click the Word file that you want to embed on your website. This will prompt it to upload into Google Drive. It shouldn't take more than a few seconds for most Word documents to upload to Drive.

steps.title: Open Google Sites.
steps.content: Open Google Sites. Go to https://sites.google.com/new in your web browser. If you aren't logged into your Google account when you do this, you'll be prompted to enter your email address and password before continuing.

steps.title: Select your Google Site.
steps.content: Select your Google Site. Click on the Google Site on which you want to insert the Word document.

steps.title: Go to the page that you want to use.
steps.content: Go to the page that you want to use. Scroll down until you arrive on the page on which you want to insert the Word document.

steps.title: Click the INSERT tab.
steps.content: Click the INSERT tab. It's in the upper-left side of the Google Sites window.

steps.title: Click From Drive.
steps.content: Click From Drive . This option is below the "Google Drive" heading near the top of the page.

steps.title: Select the document.
steps.content: Select the document. In the right-hand column, click the document that you want to insert.

steps.title: Click INSERT.
steps.content: Click INSERT . It's in the lower-right corner of the page. This will place the Word document on your website.

steps.title: Resize the document.
steps.content: Resize the document. Click and drag the top or bottom of the document to adjust its vertical size, or click and drag one of its sides to adjust the overall size of the document on your site.

steps.title: Click PUBLISH.
steps.content: Click PUBLISH . It's the purple button in the top-right corner of the page. This will update your website with your uploaded document; you should now be able to see your Word document embedded in your Google Site.

steps.title: Open WordPress.
steps.content: Open WordPress. Go to https://wordpress.com/ in your web browser. While you can't embed an image of your document on a WordPress domain, you can embed a link that downloads the WordPress file when clicked. If you aren't logged into your WordPress account, first click Log In in the top-right corner of the page, then enter your email address and password.

steps.title: Click My Site.
steps.content: Click My Site . It's in the upper-left corner of the WordPress page. Doing so will load your site's page.

steps.title: Click View Site.
steps.content: Click View Site . This option is in the upper-left side of the page.

steps.title: Click Visit Site.
steps.content: Click Visit Site . It's in the upper-right side of the page. This will take you to your site.

steps.title: Go to the page that you want to use.
steps.content: Go to the page that you want to use. Click the tab for the page on which you want to insert your Word document link; you'll usually find these tabs at the top of the page.

steps.title: Click Edit.
steps.content: Click Edit . You'll find this option in the bottom-right side of the page.

steps.title: Choose a place for your link.
steps.content: Choose a place for your link. Click on the page the place in which you want to insert a link for your Word document.

steps.title: Click ＋ Add.
steps.content: Click ＋ Add . This is a button on the left side of the page. A pop-up menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Media.
steps.content: Click Media . It's an option near the top of the pop-up menu. Doing so opens a page with all of your website's stored media.

steps.title: Click Add New.
steps.content: Click Add New . This is in the upper-left side of the page that opens.

steps.title: Select a Word document.
steps.content: Select a Word document. Click the Word document that you want to use on your site, then click Open in the bottom-right corner of the window. This will upload the Word document to the storage section of WordPress.

steps.title: Select the uploaded document.
steps.content: Select the uploaded document. Click the Word document to do so.

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . It's in the bottom-right side of the window. This will insert a link to your Word document.

steps.title: Change the link text.
steps.content: Change the link text. If you want the link text to say something other than the Word document's name, select the link once, click the pencil-shaped icon next to the link that appears, change the text in the "Link Text" field, and click Save .

steps.title: Click Update.
steps.content: Click Update . It's a blue button in the top-right corner of the page. This will update your website with your uploaded document, allowing you to click the embedded link to download the Word document.

steps.title: Upload the Word document to your website's root folder.
steps.content: Upload the Word document to your website's root folder. When hosting your own website, you should have a folder that contains the resources (e.g., pictures) that appear on your website. You'll need to place your Microsoft Word document in this folder. This step will depend heavily upon the software that you use to host your website.

steps.title: Copy the Word document's address.
steps.content: Copy the Word document's address. Again, this step will depend on the software that you use to host your website, but you can usually find the address in a URL bar at the top of the page. Click and drag your mouse across the address to select it, then press Ctrl + C (Windows) or ⌘ Command + C (Mac).

steps.title: Open your website's code document.
steps.content: Open your website's code document. Open the text or HTML document in which your website's code is stored.

steps.title: Select a place for the link.
steps.content: Select a place for the link. Find the place in which you want to insert the link for your Word document, then click that place.

steps.title: Create the HREF tag.
steps.content: Create the HREF tag. Type in <a href= into your text editor.

steps.title: Paste in the Word document's address.
steps.content: Paste in the Word document's address. Press Ctrl + V (Windows) or ⌘ Command + V (Mac).

steps.title: Close the HREF tag.
steps.content: Close the HREF tag. Type in > to close the tag. You should now have a line of text that reads <a href= link > here.

steps.title: Enter the link text.
steps.content: Enter the link text. Type in the text that you want to use as the link on which someone clicks. You'll do this immediately after the closed HREF tag. For example, if you want people to click on a link that says "click here", you'd have <a href= link >click here written.

steps.title: Add the closed link tag.
steps.content: Add the closed link tag. On the right side of the link text that you want to use, type in and press ↵ Enter . This completes the link. Your line of text should now look like this: click here

steps.title: Refresh your website.
steps.content: Refresh your website. Once the website's code is updated, you should be able to click the link that you just introduced to download the Word document.
